TextView.android:text: How to use USB source
What USB devices can be used?
The app is tested mostly with DJI Osmo Action 4 in 'Webcam' mode. The camera has to be connected directly to the phone with one USB-C to USB-C cable. Both video and audio should work.
I think it's reasonable for this app to target action cameras that have 'Webcam' mode or lightweight HDMI capture cards such as Elgato Cam Link.
Elagato Cam Link and similar capture cards
Elgato Cam Link can be used with GoPro via Media Mod or Sony X3000 (as it has HDMI out). I already have these devices, so I can test if they work.

With some phones Elgato Cam Link or similar might not have audio. If you publish stream with audio state like this stream might be unplayable in OBS. I've added Bluetooth audio toggle that can add Bluetooth audio as a source for this case. Alternatively, if capture card can work via USB hub you can use some other USB audio device. Make sure to connect it after you connect capture card. Last UBS audio device connected becomes the default audio input.

I also recommend monitoring USB source with Bluetooth headphones. When both USB audio device and Bluetooth headphones are connected phones usually use USB audio as input and Bluetooth as output. On my phone I can choose where to output audio, so I can force Bluetooth if needed. That way you can hear audio from USB device via Bluetooth.
How about other HDMI capture cards?
As for other HDMI capture cards - you'll have to test and see if they work. Try to have as little USB adapters and hubs as possible between capture card and the phone.
I tested Elgato HD60 S+ and HD60 X. Elgato HD60 S+ can sort of work without audio. With HD60 X I mostly get black screen.
Disable HDCP to capture PS5, Xbox, etc.
Sometimes I forget this too when I test capture cards with PS5 - if HDCP is enabled they can't capture video. You have to disable HDCP in console settings to make it work.
Test with USB Camera (Pro) and CameraFi apps first

I recommend using USB Camera (Pro) or CameraFi apps first to test if USB device works with your Android device. They've been around for many years, so they might've done extra fixes to work better with different USB devices. LifeStreamer app supports less formats.

LifeStreamer app simply uses USB/UVC library without any additional modifications. It uses libusb and libuvc + some other stuff. I am not an expert in this area, so I can't do any special changes to make more devices work.
Note on USB audio
By default, once you plug any audio device into USB, system automatically uses it as the default audio output and input.

LifeStreamer shows the default audio input as 'Microphone' in the top right corner of the main screen. This can be either the built-in microphone of the phone, USB audio, Bluetooth mic or 3.5mm if you still have that. Only for RTMP source app will say 'Media Projection Audio' in the top right corner.
To emphasize: once you plug any USB audio device into your phone, that device instantly becomes your audio input in LifeStreamer. You don't have to switch to USB source to use it.
USB audio is lower quality when USB video is used

I test mostly with Samsung phones. I've noticed phone lowers audio quality of USB audio when USB video is used. It seems to happen on the low level, that I can't control from the app side. So I can't make the phone give higher quality audio. Just something to be aware of.
App needs a good audio source to produce playable SRT stream

If USB audio is bad and you start publishing SRT stream - it can create SRT stream that is unplayable by players and OBS. For Elgato Cam Link if it has issues with audio I recommened to use USB hub, connect Cam Link first, then connect some other USB audio device. Phone automatically switches to the last USB device connected and uses that as audio output and input. That way you can use some other USB audio device as audio input with video from Cam Link.
How to monitor USB audio?
In the bottom left corner of the main screen there is a button to enable audio monitoring. It will play audio input that goes to stream via default audio output.

When USB audio device is connected it's instantly used as the default audio input and output. If you connect USB headphones - they have both audio output and input, so you should be able to hear yourself fine. When you connect DJI OA4 or Elgato Cam Link these devices don't have audio output and that creates a problem - you can't monitor their audio.

The solution is to connect Bluetooth headphones. This allows to hear HDMI/USB audio through them. Phone doesn't switch audio input to Bluetooth automatically when USB audio device is connected, so you can still use USB audio input while monitoring audio through Bluetooth headphones.
